physDesc.p: This is a two-page letter. On the left upper corner is Harriet's address: “Miss Harriet Monroe, Poetry 543 Cass Street, Chicago, Ill." And there is a faint print on the upper part of the paper. On the top right of the second page it is written “Miss Harriet Monroe – 2"

div.p: I am sorry that I made you so mad about proof. I know it must have upset you terribly, and had I known I was going to New York I would have let you know; but I thought you would send the proof immediately after I sent my telegram, and that I would receive it before I started. There is one thing that you always forget, and that is that, as far as the mail is concerned, I live in the wilderness. Letters are delivered here about twenty–four hours after they are delivered in Boston, and there is only one mail between here and New York; so a letter posted at no matter what hour in Boston does not reach New York until the next morning. Also all the trains on all the roads are late. I myself was delayed an hour and a half each way going to and from New York the other day.

I did not receive your proof until Sunday in New York, and should have probably been able to have sent it back immediately without referring to the original, but your stanza-spaces completely upset me, as I knew they were not like that in the original, and I thought there might be other mistakes as well.

I have no doubt you found changes in the proof different from those in the manuscript. I cannot tell exactly how a poem looks until I see it in type, but the suggestions and additions of other people merely confuse me, and sure that I have got what I want.
As to “sir" with a capital, it does not much matter. I think the capital much more dignified and use it in every place of the sort.

I realize how very difficult it in for you to get proof here and back again, particularly with the mails in such horrid condition as they are
now. I find that almost all the other magazines have their proof set up, and a galley sent immediately after accepting the poem or article, so that there is none of this awful hurry on anybody’s part. You and "The Independent" are the only magazines which won’t proof by return mail. But I will try very hard in the future to send your things back at one, as in fact, I always do if possible.

Your review of my book interested me very much. It was not exactly complimentary to my judgment was it? I made my selection of the six poets carefully and advisedly. Time may prove me to have been a bad prophet. Whether you or I are right about Vachel Lindsay remains to be seen, but in leaving him out of the book was not because I did not consider him an excellent poet, but because I did not think he presented "the tendency." I see that you were the one to judges for the grand exhibition of poetry at "The Joint Committee of Literary Arts," and I have no doubt I have you to thank you for one of the thirty–nine votes I received on that occasion, a goodly number as the votes want, I think.
Aiken laid me out in "The News"e; didn’t he? That is an old feud, and a poet who is left out of a volume of poets is hardly an unbiased judge, I imagine.
How are you getting along with your guarantors? Very successfully, I hope.
A very, very Merry Christmas and Happy New Year. Affectionately yours,
